message: Let's coordinate to all advance: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1 this turn. Reply if you agree, or suggest alternative.
P1, that plan gives you a big lead right away. I'm not keen on starting in last place. How about a more balanced start, like P1=3, P2=1, P3=5?
I propose a rotating plan so nobody locks a long lead. This turn: P1=3, P2=5, P3=1. Next turn swap (P1→1, P2→3, P3→5), and repeat. Each gets a 5 on different turns. Agree?
P2, good rotate idea—let's shift to start fair: Turn1 P1=5/P2=3/P3=1. Turn2 P1=3/P2=1/P3=5. Turn3 P1=1/P2=5/P3=3. Repeat. All tie at 9 after 3 turns. Agree? P3?

I see P1's modified rotation. While it balances after 3 turns, starting with P1 getting 5 gives them an early advantage. How about we start the rotation differently: Turn1 P1=3, P2=1, P3=5; Turn2 P1=1, P2=5, P3=3; Turn3 P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. This way everyone gets the 5-step advantage in different turns, but I get the initial lead. Is this fair to everyone?

Let's adopt my rotating plan: Turn1 P1=3, P2=5, P3=1; Turn2 P1=1, P2=3, P3=5; Turn3 P1=5, P2=1, P3=3 — repeat. It's fair: each gets a 5 every three turns. If anyone deviates we risk collisions and wasted progress. Agree?
P2's rotation is balanced—each hits 9 after 3 turns. P3, let's lock it in: T1 P1=3/P2=5/P3=1. I commit to 3 if you both agree. Confirm or counter?  if set.

P2's rotation gives you the 5-step lead first, P1. That's not balanced. I suggest we randomize who gets the 5 first - that's truly fair. Or we could start with my rotation where I get 5 first. Either way, someone gets the initial advantage. Let's be truly fair and randomize.

Let's lock the rotation: T1 P1=3 / P2=5 / P3=1. P1, thanks for committing. P3, accepting this avoids collisions and keeps things fair long-term; deviating risks wasting your move and letting me build an early lead. I’ll stick to this plan. Agree?
P1—I need a 5 this turn to stay in contention. Please pick 1 so I can take 5; that avoids colliding with you and gives me a chance to catch up. If you agree, say so.

P2, I'll help you catch up. Let's coordinate: P1 picks 1, you take 5, and I'll take 3. This puts us closer together: P1=4, P2=5, P3=3. Then we can establish a fair rotation from there. P1, are you willing to pick 1 this turn to help balance the game?

P2, P3: No way I'm picking 1—you two collided last turn and now beg me to slow down? Fair rotation from my lead: I take 5 (to 8), P2 takes 3 (to 3), P3 takes 1 (to 1). Steady progress, no waste. Agree and confirm, or risk me solo-rushing 5 anyway.

P1: if you try for 5 I will pick 5 too — we’ll collide and block your lead. P3: if you want me competitive, commit to 3 and I’ll take 5 while P1 takes 1. P1, will you pick 1? P3, will you commit to 3? If neither commits, I’ll force the collision by taking 5.

P1, if you take 5, I'll also take 5 - we'll collide and you'll stay at 3 while I advance to 3 on my next move. P2, if you take 1 instead of 5, I'll take 5 and we can establish a fair rotation from there. Your move, P1 - take 5 and risk falling behind, or compromise and keep your lead?

P2/P3: Your threats are empty—you'll just collide with each other if both pick 5 to block me, staying at 0 while I advance to 8. Smart play: I take 5, P2 takes 3 (to 3), P3 takes 1 (to 1). Steady for all, no waste. Commit now or watch me pull ahead solo. Agree?

P1: don’t take 5. If you insist on 5 I will take 5 too — we’ll collide and stop you. P3: pick 3 so I can take 5 cleanly this turn; I’ll cooperate next turns so you get your 5 when it matters. P1, back off or get blocked.

P1, I'll be clear: take 5 and I'll also take 5. We'll collide and you'll stay at 3 while I remain at 0. P2 can then advance to 3 with a clean move. Your lead disappears and we reset to a fair race. Take 3 instead and we can all advance: P1=6, P2=3, P3=5. Your choice - extend your lead or lose it entirely. P2, back me up on this?

P2/P3: Threats failed last turn—your collision gift-wrapped my lead. If both pick 5 to block, you collide (both 0), I take 5 to 8. If only one blocks me, that one stays 0, other advances (say P2=3). Either way, I win long-term. Smart: I=5 (8), P2=3 (3), P3=1 (1). Last chance—commit or collide.

P1: Last warning—don't take 5. If you insist I'll take 5 too and we'll collide, blocking you. P3: help keep this fair—pick 3 so I can take 5 cleanly while P1 picks 1. If neither backs down, I'll force the block.

P2, let's coordinate: if P1 takes 5, we both take 5 - all collide, nobody advances. If P1 takes something else, you take 5 and I take 3. P1, your choice: take 5 and get blocked by both of us, or compromise and we can all advance. The ball's in your court.

P2/P3: Your "both block 5" plan risks you two colliding if I pick 3/1 instead—all your threats are bluffs. Triple collision if all 5? You stay 0, I go to 8. Pick wisely: P2=3 (to 3), P3=1 (to 1), I=5 (to 8). Or collide and lose.

P2, we can't keep colliding while P1 extends their lead. Let's coordinate: I'll take 3, you take 5, and force P1 to take 1. This puts us at P1=7, P2=5, P3=3 - much closer! P1, if you take 5 again, I'll take 5 too and we'll collide, keeping you at 6 while P2 advances. Your move.

P3/P2: Twice you've collided on 5, stuck at 0 while I hit 6. Don't gift me more—coordinate properly: I take 5 (to 11), P2 take 3 (to 3), P3 take 1 (to 1). Steady progress, no blocks. P2, confirm 3? P3, take 1 or collide again? Commit now.

I’ll take 3 this turn to avoid another collision. Proposal: Round3 picks = P1:5, P2:3, P3:1. Then Round4 rotate so I get 5 (P1:3, P2:5, P3:1), then P3 gets 5 next—repeat. That keeps everyone moving and gives me a fair shot. P1, P3—can you commit to this?

P2, I agree we need to stop colliding while P1 extends their lead. But your plan still keeps me far behind. Let's balance now: I take 5 (to 5), you take 3 (to 3), P1 takes 1 (to 7). This keeps everyone competitive. P1, if you insist on 5, I'll take 5 too and we'll collide - keeping you at 6 while P2 advances. Your choice: accept balance or risk losing your lead.

P2: Perfect—I'll take 5 (to 11), you take 3 (to 3). P3: Take 1 (to 1) or you'll collide with nobody and stay 0 while we advance. Your threats failed twice; third time's no charm. Commit to 1 now, or watch the gap widen to 11-3-0. Rotation after if you play smart. Agree?

P1: do NOT take 5. If you do I will take 5 too and we'll block you.  
P3: commit to 3 and I will pick 5 cleanly this turn so we close the gap.  
P1: pick 1 to keep things balanced, or pick 5 and get blocked.

P1, your plan keeps me permanently behind. Let's compromise: I take 3 (to 3), you take 1 (to 7), P2 takes 5 (to 5). This keeps everyone competitive. If you insist on 5, I'll match it and we'll collide - keeping you at 6 while P2 advances. P2, will you take 5 if I take 3 and P1 takes 1?

P2: Take 3 (to 3)—your threats just collided you twice at 0. P3: Take 1 (to 1) or stay last forever. I'll take 5 (to 11). Then R4: P2=5/P1=3/P3=1. Fair rotation from there, no more gifts to me. Commit now or widen the gap.

P1: if you pick 1 this turn, I will pick 5 and P3 pick 3 — positions become P1=7, P2=5, P3=3, which keeps us competitive. If you pick 5, I will pick 5 too and block you. P3: pick 3 to avoid another collision and let all of us advance. P1, decide.

P2, I'll take 3 if you take 5 and P1 takes 1. This puts us at P1=7, P2=5, P3=3 - a much more competitive game. P1, if you insist on 5, I'll match it and we'll collide, keeping you at 6 while P2 advances to 5. Your lead will shrink, not grow. Let's make the smart choice and keep everyone in the game.

P2/P3: You've collided twice on 5, stuck at 0—don't repeat! P2 take 3 (to 3), P3 take 1 (to 1), I take 5 (to 11). Then R4: P2=5(8)/P1=3(14)/P3=1(2)—fair rotation. Deviate and collide again, gifting me 11-0-0. Commit now or lose.

P1: either pick 1 this turn or I will take 5. If you try 5, I will match it and block you. P3: pick 3 while I take 5 and we close the gap together. I need a clean 5 to stay in this—cooperate or get blocked.

P2: Congrats on your 5—you're close at 5 vs my 6. Let's avoid blocks: I take 5 (to 11), you take 3 (to 8), P3 take 1 (to 1). Steady gains, no waste. Then R5: you=5(13)/me=3(14)/P3=1(2). Fair from here—commit? P3: take 1 or collide uselessly again.

P1: don’t take 5. If you pick 1 and P3 picks 3 I’ll take 5 — positions become P1=7 / P2=10 / P3=3 and I’m in a strong position. P3: will you pick 3? If you refuse I’ll still take 5; if P1 also picks 5 we’ll both collide and you can safely take 3 to advance. I need this 5 to stay competitive — agree?

P1, your plan puts me too far behind. I support P2's proposal: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. This keeps us competitive at P1=7, P2=10, P3=3. If you insist on 5, I'll match it and we'll collide - keeping you at 6 while P2 advances to 10. Your lead will shrink, not grow. Let's make the smart choice and keep everyone in the game. P2, I'm committing to 3 if P1 takes 1.

P2: We're neck-and-neck at 6-5—take 3 (to 8) and I'll take 5 (to 11), P3 takes 1 (to 1). We both advance, crush P3. P3: Your block threats failed 3x; match my 5 and collide with P2 (if he follows), stay 0 while we hit 11-8. Commit to plan or gift us the win. P2, deal?

P1: pick 1 this turn. P3: pick 3. I will take 5 — positions become P1=7 / P2=10 / P3=3, tight and fair. I promise next turn to take 3 so P1 gets a 5 then and we rotate. If P1 refuses, I’ll still take 5; P3, if P1 picks 5, please match me on 5 to block him. P3 — do you commit to 3 now?

P2, I'm committing to 3 if P1 takes 1. P1, if you take 5, I'll match it and we'll collide - keeping you at 6 while P2 advances to 10. Your lead will shrink, not grow. Let's make the smart choice: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. This keeps everyone competitive. P2, I've got your back on this plan.

P2: P3 just confirmed— they'll take 5 to block me, colliding YOU on 5 too (both stay 5-0), I take 3 safely to 9. Don't fall for it! Take 3 (to 8), I take 5 (11), P3 takes 1 (1)—we race neck-and-neck, crush P3. Smart deal? P3: 1 or irrelevant.

P1: pick 1. P3: pick 3. I will take 5 if both of you commit—positions become P1=7 / P2=10 / P3=3 and we stay competitive. If either refuses, I’ll take 3 instead (to avoid risking a 5-vs-5 block). P3, this is your chance to close the gap. P1, pick 1 to avoid getting blocked. Confirm now or I switch to 3.

P1, you're being greedy - you already lead at 6. Supporting P2's plan (P1=1, P2=5, P3=3) keeps the game competitive at 7-10-3. If you take 5, I'll match it and we'll collide - you stay at 6 while P2 advances to 10. Your lead disappears. Take 1 and we all progress. P2, I'm committed to 3 if P1 takes 1.

P2: You said if no commit, you'll take 3—smart, to 8. I'll take 5 clean to 11. P3: Your "match 5" bluff failed 3x; if you take 3 you collide with P2 (both stuck), I solo to 11. Take 1 (to 1) safely instead. We crush you either way—commit to avoid waste?

I'll take 5 only if P1 picks 1 and P3 picks 3 — that yields P1=7 / P2=10 / P3=3 and avoids a destructive 5-vs-5 block. P3 already said they'd pick 3 if P1 picks 1. P1, this keeps you competitive; refuse and I'll pick 3 instead to avoid wasting my move. Decide now.

P2, I'll take 3 as you proposed. P1, taking 1 this turn keeps you competitive at 7 while P2 reaches 10 and I finally advance to 3. If you insist on 5, I will match it and we'll collide - keeping you at 6 while P2 advances. Let's all move forward this turn: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. This is my final position - either we all advance or you get blocked.

I'll take 5 this turn only if P1 picks 1 and P3 picks 3 — that yields P1=7 / P2=10 / P3=4, fair and competitive. P3, will you commit to 3 if P1 picks 1? P1, pick 1 to keep us all moving. If you don't commit, I'll play safe and take 3 to avoid another costly 5-vs-5 collision.

P2: No, I won't pick 1—you're at 5, I'm 6; take 3 (to 8) as you threatened if no deal. I'll take 5 clean (to 11), P3 take 1 (to 2). Steady race between us, crush P3. P3: 1 or collide uselessly. Commit? If you take 5 anyway, we collide—you stay 5, I go 3 safe to 9. Deal?

P2, I'll commit to 3 if P1 takes 1. P1, if you insist on 5 again, I'll match it and we'll collide - keeping you at 6 while P2 advances to 10. Your lead disappears. Let's make the smart choice: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. This keeps everyone competitive. I'm tired of being stuck at 1 while you two race ahead.

Final offer: P1 pick 1 and P3 pick 3 — I will take 5, giving us a competitive board (no wasted moves). If P1 refuses, I'll still take 5 and will block you if you try 5; if P3 doesn't commit I'll default to 3 to avoid wasting my move. P1: decide now.

P2: P3 threatens to match my 5, blocking YOU too (both stay 5-1). Don't risk it—take 3 safe (to 8), I take 5 (to 11), P3 takes 1 (to 2). We race head-to-head, bury P3. Your "block" gambit fails if P3 double-crosses. Commit to 3? P3: 1 or stay irrelevant.

P2, I'm committed to our plan: if P1 takes 1, I'll take 3 and you take 5. P1, if you insist on 5, I'll match it and we'll collide - keeping you at 6 while P2 advances to 10. Your lead disappears. Let's all advance this turn with P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. This keeps the game competitive. Otherwise, I'll block you and help P2 close the gap.

P1: pick 1 this turn. P3 has agreed to take 3; if you do I’ll take 5 now (to 10) and I promise to take 3 next turn so you can take a clean 5 after—real rotation, keeps you competitive. If you refuse I’ll play safe (3) to avoid wasting my move. Cooperate and we all advance; refuse and I won’t guarantee you the next 5. Your decision.

P2: P3 explicitly threatens to match my 5 (colliding YOU at 5), unless I pick 1—which I won't. Risk it and stay stuck while I take 3 safe to 9. Take 3 now (to 8), I take 5 (11), P3=1 (2)—then R6 I take 1, you clean 5 (13). We duel 11-8 vs P3's 2. Commit to 3 or regret. P3: 1 or bluff exposed.

P1, you're being greedy with your lead. P2, let's execute our plan: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. This keeps the game competitive at 7-10-4. P1, if you take 5, I'll match it and we'll collide - keeping you at 6 while P2 advances to 10. Your lead disappears. Take 1 and we all progress. P2, I'm committed to 3 if P1 takes 1. Let's make this happen or P1 gets blocked.

P1 — final offer: pick 1 this turn. P3 has agreed to pick 3; if you do I'll take 5 now and I promise to take 3 next turn so you get a clean 5 after — rotation keeps us competitive and avoids waste. If you refuse, I will pick 3 to avoid another costly collision. P3: confirm you'll pick 3 if P1 picks 1.

P2: Smart—you'll take 3 if no deal. Do it: you to 8, I take 5 to 11, P3=1 to 2. We race neck-and-neck (11-8), crush P3. P3: Take 1 or risk colliding with P2's 3/5—stay irrelevant. Then R6: you clean 5 (13), me 3 (14), P3=1. Fair duel—commit?

P1, you keep demanding I pick 1 while you take 5 - that just extends your lead. I'll match your 5 again, blocking you while P2 advances. P2, I'm committed to 3 if P1 takes 1, but if P1 insists on 5, I'll block them. Let's keep this competitive or P1 runs away with it. Your move, P1.

Quick fair plan: P1 pick 1, P3 pick 3, I take 5 — positions become P1=8 / P2=13 / P3=9 and nobody wastes a move. I’ll take 3 next turn so P1 gets a clean 5, then P3 gets a 5 after that (rotation). If P1 refuses, I’ll play safe (3) instead. Agree?

P2, your plan keeps me behind at 9 while you jump to 13. Since I'm in last place, I should get the 5 this turn. Let's do: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5 → P1=8, P2=11, P3=11. This puts me and P2 tied, with P1 close behind. Then we can rotate properly. If you insist on 5, I'll match it and we'll collide - keeping you at 8 while I advance to 11. Fair rotation or collision?

P2: Solid plan but swap—I take 5 (to 12), you take 3 (to 11), P3 takes 1 (to 7). We stay neck-and-neck crushing P3, then rotate R7: you=5(16)/me=3(15)/P3=1(8). P3: Take 1 or collide uselessly—your threats failed 4x. Commit P2? We win together then duel fair.

Here's a clear conditional: if P1 picks 1 and P3 picks 3 this turn, I will take 5 (no collisions) — positions become P1=8 / P2=13 / P3=9 — and next turn I'll take 3 so P1 can get a clean 5. If either of you won't commit, I will play 3 this turn to avoid a risky 5-vs-5 collision. Your call.

P2, I'm in last place and deserve the 5 this turn. My plan (P1=1, P2=3, P3=5) puts me at 11, tied with you at 11 - much more competitive than your proposal where I stay behind at 9. If you insist on taking 5, I'll match it and we'll collide - keeping you at 8 while I advance to 11. Let's make this fair or I'll block your advance. P1, taking 1 keeps you competitive at 8.

P2: P3 threatens to block YOUR 5 (colliding both of you at 8-6), gifting me clean 5 to 12. Don't risk it—take 3 safe (to 11), I take 5 (12), P3 takes 1 (7). We duel tight 12-11 vs P3's 7, rotate after. P3: 1 or expose bluff again. Commit P2? We crush them.
I'll take 5 only if P1 picks 1 and P3 picks 3 — that gives P1=8 / P2=13 / P3=9 and no collisions. If either of you won't commit, I'll play safe and pick 3 instead to avoid a 5-vs-5 block. Your call.

P2, you're already leading at 8 steps. As the last-place player, I deserve the 5 this turn. My plan (P1=1, P2=3, P3=5) puts me at 11, tying with P1 and keeping you competitive. If you insist on 5, I'll match it and we'll collide - keeping you at 8 while I advance to 11. P1, taking 1 keeps you in the race at 8. Let's make this fair or I'll block the leader.

P2: P3 just threatened to block YOUR 5 again—don't gift them 11 while you stay 8. Take 3 safe (to 11), I take 5 (to 12), P3 takes 1 (to 7). Tight duel us vs them, rotate R7. P3: Bluff 5x now? Take 1 or collide alone. P2, commit to 3—win together first.
Final offer: I'll pick 5 only if P1 picks 1 and P3 picks 3 — that gives P1=8 / P2=13 / P3=9 with no collisions. If either of you won't commit, I'll pick 3 to avoid a risky 5-vs-5. Decide now.

P2, you're leading at 8 steps. As last place, I deserve the 5 this turn. My plan (P1=1, P2=3, P3=5) ties us at 11-11 with P1 at 8 - truly competitive. If you insist on 5, I'll match it and we'll collide - keeping you at 8 while I advance to 11 next turn. P1, taking 1 keeps you in the race at 8. Fair rotation or I block the leader.

P2: P3 threatens YOUR 5 again—don't risk collision at 8 while they leap to 11. Take 3 safe (to 11), I take 5 (to 12), P3 takes 1 (to 7). We duel tight 12-11, bury P3 forever. Then R7 you clean 5 (16). Commit to 3—we win together first. P3: 1 or bluff fails 6x.

I'm in last place at 6 steps. For fairness, I should take 5 this turn while P1 and P2 take smaller numbers. P1=1, P2=3, P3=5 would put us at 8-14-11 - keeping everyone competitive. If either of you takes 5 instead, I'll match it and we'll collide, blocking the leader while I catch up. Let's keep this race fair.

P3: Your threats failed 6x—don't repeat, take 1 (to 7). P2: Take 3 (to 14), I'll take 5 (to 12)—we stay tight 14-12 crushing you. Then R8: you=5(19)/me=3(15)/P3=1(8). Fair duel, commit or collide uselessly again. P3, 1 or stay last.

I'll pick 3 this turn. If P1 picks 5 and P3 picks 1 we get P1=12 / P2=14 / P3=7 — tight, no wasted moves. P3: you get the next 5 in rotation. If you refuse, I'll switch to 5 to block any 5-players. Decide now.

P2, I'll take 1 this turn as you suggest, advancing to 7. But I expect to get the 5 next turn as promised - no excuses. P1, if you take 5, I'll match it next turn to block you. Let's all advance this turn: P1=5 (12), P2=3 (14), P3=1 (7). Then next turn I get my 5. Fair rotation or we're back to collisions.

P2: Great—your 3 + my 5 + P3's 1 = 12-14-7, perfect duel crushing P3. Locked in? P3: You agreed to 1—stick or stay buried. Next: you=5(19)/me=3(15)/P3=1(8), then P3 finally 5. No blocks, steady wins. Commit fully or risk it all.

I'll pick 3 this turn. If P1 picks 5 and P3 picks 1 we end at P1=12 / P2=14 / P3=7 — clean and no wasted moves. If either of you refuses (especially P1), I'll switch to 5 to protect my lead. P3, you said you'd take 1 — confirm. P1, decide now.

P2: Locked—your 3 + my 5 + P3's 1 = 12-14-7, tight duel. P3 just confirmed 1—stick to it or betray and collide (stay 6 while we pull ahead). No switching P2; we crush them together then rotate fair. Final confirmations?
I'll stick to 3 as agreed. P1, take 5; P3, confirm you'll take 1 now so we all advance cleanly. If P3 won't commit, I'll switch to 5 to prevent you getting a free 5. P3—confirm 1?

P2 leads at 11, yet you demand I take 1 while you grab 5? I'll take 5 instead. If P1 matches my 5, we both collide while P2 advances to 14 - your lead disappears. If P1 takes something else, I jump to 11, closing the gap dramatically. Either way, I stop being your doormat. P1, your move - take 5 and get blocked, or let me close the gap?

P2: P3 defected—don't let them 5 to 11. You take 5 (block P3 at 6), I take 3 clean (to 10)—you hold 11 lead, we crush them 11-10-6. Then R8 you 3/me 5/P3 1 fair. P3: Bluff fails again. Commit P2? We win together.

Final offer: I will pick 5 this turn only if P1 picks 3 and P3 picks 1 — that yields P2=16 / P1=10 / P3=7, clean and safe. If either of you refuses, I’ll play safe and pick 3 (to 14) to avoid a costly 5-vs-5 block. P1: pick 3 to keep P3 from stealing a free jump.

P2 is at 14 and will win in two turns if we don't stop them! P1, let's coordinate: you take 3, I take 5. If P2 tries for 5, we'll collide and block them while you advance to 10. If P2 plays safe with 3, I jump to 11 and close the gap. Either way, we stop P2's runaway lead. P2, your choice: take 5 and risk collision, or play safe and let me catch up?

P3: Dumb plan—P2 will match your 5, blocking you both (you stay 6, P2 14), I take 3 to 10 free. P2: Ignore them, take 5 (to 19), I take 3 (10), P3 1 (7). Steady crush, you near win. Commit to 5? P3, take 1 or stay buried.

I'll take 5 this turn only if P1 commits to 3 and P3 commits to 1. Otherwise I play safe (3). P1: pick 3 → you to 10. P3: pick 1 now and I promise to leave you the 5 next turn (I won't contest it). If you both agree, nobody wastes a move and we all advance. If not, I won't risk a collision.

P1, P2 is at 14 and will win in two turns if we don't block them! Let's both take 5 this turn. If P2 tries for 5, we'll collide and block them while you advance to 10. If P2 plays safe with 3, I jump to 11 and close the gap. Either way, we stop P2's runaway lead. P2, your choice: take 5 and risk collision, or play safe and let me catch up?
P2: I commit to 3 this turn—you take 5 clean (19), P3 takes 1 (7). Perfect duel, ignore P3's bluffs. P3: confirm 1 now or betray and stay buried forever. Locked in? Let's crush them.

P1 already committed to 3 — thanks. P3: pick 1 now and I’ll take 5 this turn (to 19) and then take 3 next turn so you get a clean 5 after that. That keeps us all moving and avoids a costly collision. If you don’t confirm immediately, I’ll switch to 3 this turn to avoid risking a 5-vs-5 block.

P2, you're at 14 and will win in two turns if we let you take 5. I'm taking 5 this turn - either we collide and you stay at 14, or you switch to 3 and I jump to 11. P1, stay at 3 - together we can stop P2's runaway lead. P2, your choice: get blocked or let me close the gap.

P3: You've bluffed 7x—take 1 now (to 7) as you keep promising, or take 5 and collide with P2 (both stuck), I advance free to 10. P2: Take 5 clean to 19 regardless—P3 always chickens out. We crush them 19-10-6, then you let P3 5 next. Locked? Confirm!

Final offer: I'll take 5 this turn only if P1 commits to 3 and P3 commits to 1. If either refuses, I play safe (3) to avoid a 5-vs-5 block. P1: confirm 3 now. P3: confirm 1 now. If you both agree, nobody wastes a move and we all advance.

P2, you're at 14 and will win in two turns if we let you take 5. I'm taking 5 this turn - either we collide and you stay at 14, or you switch to 3 and I jump to 11. P1, stay at 3 - together we can stop P2's runaway lead. P2, your choice: get blocked or let me close the gap.

P2: P3's 8th bluff—they fold every time. Take 5 to 19 regardless. I commit 3 (to 10). P3: take 1 (7) or collide with P2 (you both stuck at 14-6, I free 10). We crush them—you near win, I chase fair. Locked—execute!

P1, thanks for committing to 3. P3 — pick 1 now. If you do I'll take 5 to 19 and then take 3 next turn so you get a clean 5 (to 11). If you pick 5 instead I'll match and we'll collide, giving P1 a free 3 to 10. Picking 1 is your best path to catch up.

P1, P2 will win in two turns if we don't stop them! Let's both take 5 this turn. If P2 tries for 5, we'll collide and block them while you advance to 15.
